text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today i'm 
going to share with you a thai waffle recipe yes

in thailand we do have a version of the waffle 
and it is different from the American or the

Belgian waffle we call it kanom rung peung kanom 
is a dessert or snack and rung peung means beehive

and that's because the pattern on the waffles are 
like the cells on the Beehive now in Thailand we

eat this more like a snack rather than a breakfast 
but here I make them I freeze them and I eat it

for breakfast all the time let's get started so 
I'm going to start by melting my palm sugar in

a pot now palm sugar is really important for this 
because it is the ingredient that's going to give

it that distinct flavor that's different from 
say an American waffle nice butterscotch aroma

so if there was one recipe where you really need 
it it's this one now to get that dissolving I am

going to add some coconut milk and yes this 
is a dairy-free waffle now I'm not going to

add all my coconut milk just enough to cover the 
sugar because right now I just need the sugar to

dissolve all right that is it and now that right 
there just coconut milk and palm sugar pour it

over ice cream delicious this alone so good now 
I'm going to add some dried shredded coconut

to this now in Thailand we actually use fresh 
shredded coconut but I can't find that here so

dry work just fine make sure it's unsweetened and 
what I want to do is I want to let the dry coconut

soak up all that liquid in the pot and I want to 
do that now because if I add it at the end and I

don't give it a chance to absorb the liquid it'll 
continue to slowly absorb it and your batter will

sort of get thicker and thicker and thicker as 
you go and then suddenly at the end you're like

why is all of us up my batter so thick now we 
need to let this cool I'm going to add the rest

of my coconut milk and a little bit of salt I'm 
going to add that now just so it dissolves more

quickly alright now I'm just going to let that 
cool until it's at room temperature and then go

move on now the dry ingredients and this is where 
things differ a little bit I've got here some all

purpose flour and rice flour and in Thailand we 
use rice flour as our main starch for desserts

gonna make these waffles really soft and tender 
this bowl is a little too big for my mini whisk

so my regular whisk is gonna have to do and I'm 
also going to add some baking powder a little

leavening to get it nice and fluffy I've got to 
EXCI I'm gonna choose now beat them really well

with my mini OS guess there's always a place for 
the mini whisk and you want to make sure there's

no gloopy bits of egg whites you want to beat 
this really really well see this is why I like

the mini whisk I'm just saying I can the rest the 
whisk in the bowl and it doesn't topple over which

always happens with the pick whisk my syrup has 
cooled I'm going to just pour the eggs now into

the syrup if you want extra extra fluffy waffles 
what you can do is take the egg whites and beat

them up like a meringue and then fold it in later 
that's what I do for my regular waffles but for

these I'm just keeping it traditional so easy 
this recipe I'm just going to pour my wet into

my dry and now I'm just going to fold everything 
together and I'm being careful not to over mix

everything but because we have so much rice flour 
in here you've got a little bit more wiggle room

because rice flour is gluten free so your chances 
of over developing gluten and making tough waffles

it's lower and just before it's completely mixed 
I'm going to add my add-ins so add-ins for Cano

blanco you have a lot of different choices sweet 
corn so this is just corn I just got this from

the can but you can get it fresh off the cop 
even better and I've just roughly chopped it so

they're not because sometimes the kernels I find 
too large but sometimes we add raisins sometimes

we add little chunks of cooked taro if you like 
that what else young coconut shredded of young

tender coconut or you can just leave them plain 
but corn is my favorite and it's sort of the one

that's easiest to work with right so now I'm just 
going to stir in my corn and that is it how easy

was that now you can use this batter right away 
if you don't have time but ideally you want to

let this rest for about 30 minutes it relaxes the 
gluten strands it allows all the starch to observe

orb all the liquid and your batter will thicken a 
little bit so you have a better judge of you know

the actual consistency of your batter and it is 
a little thinner than the regular american-style

waffle and Belgian waffle and that is just how 
Thai waffles are so in Thailand kinome Brangwyn

is a little bit thinner than the traditional 
American or Belgian waffles so the closest

waffle iron that I can get here is this sort of 
flour heart shape one which make thinner waffles

I will post a link to where I got this over here 
in case you're interested but if you just want

to use your regular the squared american-style 
waffle iron you can do that as well just know

that it will not fill up the whole way so because 
the batter is quite a bit thinner so you get like

a one-sided waffle totally fine I've done it that 
way as well just an FYI so I preheated this grille

and now I just have to cook the waffles and your 
waffle iron will dictate how much better you need

to fill it and I always like to go and make sure 
the batter reaches the very end because sometimes

if I don't the batter doesn't actually get there 
on its own it needs a little help and then I'm not

going to actually clamp the lid closed because I 
find it for this iron the waffles become too thin

so I just let its own weight the weight of the 
lid just gently sit down on the waffle and the

thickness is perfect if you're using the American 
style thicker waffle iron don't worry about it

ooh that looks nice the underside is always nicer 
because it's got a fuller contact now it's still

got a few more seconds sometimes I like to rotate 
it because this waffle iron does have hot spots

each waffle iron has its own personality so you 
kind of have to fiddle with it a little bit the

first couple of pieces are always experiments 
let's see that looks nice and the underside is

absolutely perfect it smells amazing in here you 
wouldn't believe it I had to work really hard to

not eat them as I was making them because I wanted 
to have the whole set to show you how much this

recipe makes it makes five full piece this this 
one didn't quite have enough batter at the end

so the edges are kind of jagged which is kind 
of cute actually you might want to do that so

just not fill them all the way and you just get 
these little jagged edges and so you notice this

waffle iron each section makes a heart so it's 
really cute so sometimes if I'm serving this

at a party or something I will tear it all up and 
have individual pieces so people just eat it like

snacks oh I forgot to mention these are not eaten 
with anything so there's no toppings or anything

that we put on it as I said they're more like 
afternoon snacks but if you want to put whipped

cream on it if you want to do ice cream you want 
to put more things on it you are more than welcome

to do that oh the smell of childhood I used 
to eat so much of these when I was a kid mmm

it's almost cakey but the inside is moist enough 
that it's slightly custardy as well that coconut

flavor in the palm sugar that is what makes 
this tape unique and the little chunks of

corn are like burst of sweetness and these are 
not crispy waffles by the way these are soft

tender waffles and the rice flour is what makes 
it soft and tender so they're not chewy oh this

just so it's like it reminds me also of Donuts I 
know just has the same feel like you know a sweet

taking Joey thing that you can just munch on go 
work a nice coffee with this Oh perfect so I hope

you give these a try it's so easy and if you got 
dairy-free friends these are the perfect waffles

to make for them just a note about storage so what 
I do is I make them all and even if I don't finish

as I freeze them and when i reheat I stick them 
in the toaster and they become warm and a little

bit crispy on the outside as they toast so good so 
the recipe as always will be on hot Thai Kitchen

calm when you make me send me a photo on Facebook 
Twitter or Instagram if you haven't subscribed to

the show please do so you will never miss an 
episode and I will see you next time for your

next did it just type and that right there you can 
just drizzle it over ice cream and it's perfect

just coconut milk and palm sugar delicious 
combination I'm wearing glasses yes suddenly
